ygData.subject: Re: Modular robot morphology & gait with hyperNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Evert, sounds like a great project.  I think there is enough precedent for step 1 that it could be realistically achieved.  Of course, step 2 is more

Subject: Re: Modular robot morphology & gait with hyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=vwWe9FMQ5Ug_2SlpBPrk0odGKwIPYxibziNzNVQsqKc-x2nPzhj9
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Evert, sounds like a great project.  I think there is enough precedent for =
step 1 that it could be realistically achieved.  Of course, step 2 is more =
speculative.

For step 1, my question is whether it is necessary to regard =
the individual robots that make up the full organism as being separate for =
the purposes of evolving the controller?  That is, would it not work to sim=
ply regard it as a single whole and ignore the individual separations?  Tha=
t way you could just evolve one monolithic controller for the assembly.  Ho=
wever, I can imagine that it might not be possible to do that depending on =
your communication constraints.  In any case, HyperNEAT can represent it ei=
ther way.  If the identity of each robot matters, you can certainly input t=
he location along the organism to the CPPN as additional information, and t=
hat could indeed be helpful.  

Step 2 (evolving the morphology) sounds ver=
y interesting butis a much more open problem.  I think interleaving might b=
e more effective than simply doing a meta-search in which every potential m=
orphology is evaluated through an entire evolution run to find a controller=
 for it.  That sounds very expensive.  After all, in nature both brain and =
body evolve together so presumably it can happen here too.  

Also, the rep=
resentation of the morphology (i.e. how it is translated from the CPPN outp=
ut) will be very critical and deserves careful thought. 

ken


--- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, "evertwh2004" <evert@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> I am in=
volved in a modular robotics project (www.symbrion.eu), where we are develo=
ping robots that can hook onto each other to create 'organisms' that consis=
t of linked robots. The robots can manipulate the link(s), e.g., to lift ea=
ch other. Recently, Jeff Clune (hi Jeff) introduced me to hyperNEAT, and it=
 looks like just the ticket to address two issues that we have to tackle. S=
o here I am, excited newbie and all.
> 
> First, I want to try and use hype=
rNEAT to evolve gaits for organisms with pre-defined shapes (e.g., spiders,=
 snakes). The idea is to develop a single genome that determines the weight=
s for neural nets in each of the individual robots that make up the organis=
m, so I would expect to pass the coordinates of nodes within the individual=
 NN, but also about the location of the individual in the organism (possibl=
y related to some central node or whatever).
> 
> The next step will be to =
use hyperNEAT's CPPNs to evolve morphologies for organisms. I'm thinking of=
 a 3D grid where the CPPN assigns some value to each cell which defines, ac=
cording to some threshold, whether a robot goes in that spot or not. The fi=
tness of the CPPN would be the level of success in evolving a gait for the =
resulting shape as described above. Another method of combining morphology =
and gait development would be to interleave them in some way (waves hands).=

> 
> So...does that sound like a good plan, are there any pointers to rela=
ted work? Do's and don'ts? Expressions of interest, ridicule or awe?
> 
> T=
IA,
> 
> Evert Haasdijk
> VU Amsterdam
>
